Acquisition: Acquisition Logistics
   
  Introduction  
         
 

Prior to 2003, DoD Regulation 5000.2-R devoted a section to acquisition logistics. It stated:

The Program Manager shall conduct acquisition
logistics management activities throughout the
system development to ensure the design and
acquisition of systems that can be cost-effectively
supported and to ensure that these systems are
provided to the user with the necessary support
infrastructure for achieving the user’s peacetime
and wartime readiness requirements.

To accomplish this goal, logisticians must be involved in the design phase as part of the Systems Engineering Process. Logisticians will perform supportability analyses that will form the basis for the design requirements. Logisticians will also establish support concepts that will be utilized throughout the life-cycle.

  

The new Department of Defense Regulation no longer specifically identifies how logistics support should be considered in the acquisition process. However, the need to consider logistics in the system design is still as important today as it has always been. The new language calls for “Acquisition Logistics” to be conducted throughout the system development to ensure the design and acquisition of systems can be cost-effectively supported.
